git.definition: A parallel timeline where you can try changes without affecting the main code
git.example: git checkout -b feature/search creates a new branch
git.analogy: Like a 'Choose Your Own Adventure' book - you can always go back to the main story
choices: A parallel timeline for trying changes safely
A save point in your code
The main version of your code

git.definition: A save point for your code at a specific moment in time
git.example: git commit -m 'Add PDF optimization' creates a save point
git.analogy: Like saving your game - you can always load this exact state later
choices: Create a save point of current code

git.definition: Combine changes from one branch into another
git.example: git merge feature/search brings your experiment into main
git.analogy: Like combining two versions of a document into one final version

git.definition: Download and merge changes from the remote repository (like GitHub) to your local computer
git.example: git pull gets the latest code from your team
git.analogy: Like downloading the newest version of a shared Google Doc

git.definition: Upload your local commits to the remote repository (like GitHub)
git.example: git push shares your changes with the team
git.analogy: Like uploading your work to Dropbox so others can see it

git.definition: The default name for the remote repository (usually on GitHub)
git.example: origin/main refers to the main branch on GitHub
git.analogy: Like the nickname for 'the cloud server where everyone's code lives'

git.definition: Move your branch to start from a newer point, replaying your changes on top
git.example: git rebase main moves your feature branch to the latest main
git.analogy: Like copying your edits onto the newest version of a document
choices: Move branch to start from newer code

git.definition: Download a complete copy of a repository from remote to your computer
git.example: git clone [url] downloads the entire project
git.analogy: Like downloading a complete copy of someone's project folder
choices: Download a full copy of a repository

nextjs.definition: A component that runs on the server and sends HTML to the browser (faster, can access databases)
nextjs.example: async function Page() runs on server, can fetch data directly
nextjs.analogy: Like a chef preparing food in the kitchen before bringing it to your table

nextjs.definition: A component that runs in the browser and can be interactive (needs 'use client' at top)
nextjs.example: 'use client' makes a component interactive with onClick, useState, etc.
nextjs.analogy: Like controls on your TV remote - they work on your side
choices: Runs in browser, can be interactive

nextjs.definition: A URL path in your app that shows a specific page
nextjs.analogy: Like different rooms in a house - each URL is a different room
choices: A URL path that shows a page

nextjs.definition: A backend endpoint that handles data requests (like fetching or saving)
nextjs.analogy: Like a waiter taking your order to the kitchen and bringing back food

nextjs.definition: Code that runs before a request is completed (useful for auth, redirects)
nextjs.example: middleware.ts can check if user is logged in before showing pages
nextjs.analogy: Like a security guard checking IDs before letting people in

terminal.definition: List files and folders in the current directory
terminal.example: ls shows what's in this folder
terminal.analogy: Like opening a folder to see what's inside

terminal.definition: Change directory - move to a different folder
terminal.example: cd Desktop moves you to the Desktop folder
terminal.analogy: Like walking into a different room

terminal.definition: Print working directory - show where you currently are
terminal.analogy: Like asking 'where am I right now?'

terminal.definition: Make directory - create a new folder
terminal.analogy: Like creating a new folder in Finder

terminal.definition: Remove - delete a file (use -r for folders, BE CAREFUL)
terminal.example: rm file.txt deletes the file permanently
terminal.analogy: Like moving something to trash, but emptying trash immediately

terminal.example: grep 'TODO' *.js finds all TODOs in JavaScript files
terminal.analogy: Like using Ctrl+F to find text, but across many files

react.definition: A hook that lets you add state (changeable data) to a component
react.example: const [count, setCount] = useState(0) creates a counter
react.analogy: Like a variable that remembers its value and re-renders when it changes

react.definition: A hook that runs code when component loads or when dependencies change
react.example: useEffect(() => { fetchData() }, []) runs once on load
react.analogy: Like an automatic trigger that says 'when X happens, do Y'

react.definition: Data passed from a parent component to a child component
react.example: <Button text='Click me' /> passes text as a prop
react.analogy: Like handing someone instructions or ingredients

react.definition: A reusable piece of UI (like a button, card, or page section)
react.analogy: Like a LEGO brick - build once, use many times

general.definition: Application Programming Interface - a way for programs to talk to each other
general.example: /api/editions endpoint returns edition data as JSON
general.analogy: Like a waiter - you tell them what you want, they bring it from the kitchen
choices: A way for programs to communicate

general.definition: JavaScript Object Notation - a format for storing and sending data
general.analogy: Like a labeled box: 'name: John, age: 30'
choices: A data format for storing info

general.definition: A secret or config value stored outside your code (like in .env file)
general.analogy: Like a settings file that you don't commit to git
choices: A type of variable in code
A config value stored outside code

general.definition: Stored copy of data to make future requests faster
general.example: Browser caches images so they don't re-download
general.analogy: Like keeping leftovers in the fridge instead of cooking again
